key_findings: Established global convergence rate of O(ε) between strong solutions of relaxed Euler system and porous medium equation in Rd for ill-prepared initial data, providing quantitative bounds for approximation accuracy in fluid dynamics simulations.

Achieved enhanced convergence rate of O(ε²) for well-prepared initial conditions between compressible Euler system solutions and first-order asymptotic approximations, doubling the convergence speed under optimal conditions.

Proved global strong convergence of Euler-Maxwell system solutions to drift-diffusion model in R³ with O(ε) rate, enabling accurate modeling of plasma physics and semiconductor device behavior with quantified error bounds.

Developed novel asymptotic expansion approach combined with stream function techniques that ensures uniform-in-time error estimates, providing robust mathematical framework for long-term stability analysis.

Extended theoretical framework to partially dissipative hyperbolic systems in classical Sobolev spaces, offering broader applicability to relaxation phenomena in blood flow modeling, gas dynamics, kinetic theory, and traffic flow systems.
limitations: Results are purely theoretical with no computational validation or numerical experiments provided
Analysis limited to specific mathematical spaces (Sobolev spaces) which may not cover all practical scenarios
future_work: Numerical validation of theoretical convergence rates through computational experiments
problem_addressed: Quantifying convergence rates in relaxation limits for compressible fluid dynamics systems to enable accurate approximation of complex physical phenomena
prerequisites: Advanced knowledge of partial differential equations
real_world_applications: Blood flow modeling with friction forces
